awd_titl_txt: Graphical and Categorical Methods in Representation Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is in the general area of representation theory, which in broad terms is the idea of understanding symmetries of some naturally occurring structure such as a crystal by studying the different ways in which those symmetries can be realized in terms of matrices. By looking for the common features shared by all such matrix realizations at once, mathematicians have discovered some higher structures that encode all possible symmetries between symmetries. These new structures, "monoidal categories," can often be realized in purely graphical terms. In the last few years, this point of view has revealed some quite unexpected connections between very different parts of mathematics and physics. One example that plays a role in this project is the so-called Heisenberg category, which arose originally in algebra from thinking about symmetries between representations of the finite symmetric groups, but which is also connected to the infinite-dimensional Heisenberg Lie algebra, which has its origins in quantum mechanics. The funding of this project will lead to new understanding of classical problems in representation theory by taking advantage of this graphical approach, with potential applications both inside and outside of mathematics, including to finite group theory, combinatorics, Lie theory, knot theory, and theoretical physics. This project provides research training opportunities for graduate students.

In more detail, the project will study the representation theory of algebraic groups, quantum groups and Lie superalgebras by exploiting some remarkable new pivotal monoidal categories which are defined by generators and relations. These include various Heisenberg categories whose definition is of a graphical nature. These monoidal categories act on many of the classically important categories in representation theory, leading to a unified general framework which reveals unexpected connections between different theories. The project will focus on five specific projects: Okounkov-Vershik approach to representations of the partition category; quasi-hereditary coalgebras and blocks of Deligne categories; the rational web category and thickened Heisenberg categorification; odd Heisenberg and super Kac-Moody 2-categories; Modular shifted Yangians and flag algebras.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this grant is in a relatively new area of mathematics known as diagrammatic categorification, which sits between algebra, low dimensional topology and category theory. In this project, the general diagrammatic techniques of diagrammatic categorification are being applied to much more classical questions in the representation theory of Lie groups, which are fundamental to describing symmetries that arise both in the world we live in and in many more abstract structures which appear in mathematics.

There have been several significant advances as a result of the projects in this award. The most significant is the proof of a famous conjecture, Broue's Abelian Defect Conjecture, for an important family of finite groups. This conjecture was proposed in the early 1990s and has directed much research since then. Notably, in 2004, Chuang and Rouquier proved it for all symmetric groups, which are perhaps the most fundamental of all finite groups. In this award, the PI joint with Alexander Kleshchev, also at the University of Oregon, has now been able to treat the double covers of the symmetric groups, which turned out to require many new ideas and is the culmination of 20 years of work by many researchers.

Another exciting new development is work of the PI joint with Weiqiang Wang and Ben Webster over this period leading to the discovery of a new diagrammatically-defined monoidal category known as the nil-Brauer category. This is important because this research has proved that its Grothendieck ring recovers one of the three fundamental rank one i-quantum groups. In general, i-quantum groups are a remarkable and relatively new family of deformations of symmetric pairs, which have long played a fundamental role in mathematics and mathematical physics as they provide the mathematical foundation for many important homogeneous spaces. The other two rank one i-quantum groups were categorified before, one being sl(2) whose categorificaiton played a key role in the work of Chuang and Rouquier mentioned in the previous paragraph. This work is expected to have significant implications in ongoing research aimed at finding analogous monoidal categories for all of the quasi-split i-quantum groups (not just rank one).

Another noteworthy contribution from this award is the development of a new approach to the representation theory of the partition category, obtained in joint work of the PI and a graduate student Max Vargas who was partially supported by these NSF funds. The new approach is highly dependent on the diagrammatic methods that are the general theme of all of the projects supported by this award.

Finally, the PI has also been actively involved during this period in education of younger researchers, both through research carried out with his own PhD students, and several series of expository talks given at national and international workshops.
